components.title: Basic Economic Ideas and Resource Allocation
content: The fundamental problem in economics is that resources are scarse and wants are unlimited, so there is always a choice required between competing uses for the resources.

components.title: The margin and change
content: Decision-making by individuals, firms, and governments is based on choices at the margin; that is, once behaviour has been optimised, any change will be detrimental as long as conditions remain the same.

components.title: Equilibrium and efficiency
content: Prices are set by markets, are always moving in and out of equilibrium, and can be both efficient and inefficient in different ways and over different time periods.

components.title: Regulation and equity
content: There is a trade-off between, on the one hand, freedom for firms and individuals in unregulated markets, and on the other hand, greater social equality and equity through the government regulation of individuals and markets

components.title: Progress and Development
content: Economics studies how societies can progress in measurable money terms and develop in a wider more normative sense

components.title: Physical quantities and units
content: The measurement and recording of quantities is central to the whole of physics. The skills of estimating a physical quantity and having a feeling for which quantities are reasonable and which are unreasonable are very useful for any physicist. The topic introduces the SI system of units, which provides a unversal framework of measurement that is common to all scientists internationally. Candidates should be aware of the nature of physical measurement, in terms of a magnitude and a unit. They should have experience of making and recording measurements in the laboratory.

components.title: Measurement techniques
content: Measurement is essential to the study of physics. Physicists need to be familiar with a wide range of instruments. Measurements themselves may be misleading and result in inappropriate conclusions as a result of errors and uncertainties in measured and derived path of physical quantities.

components.title: Kinematics
content: Kinematics is the study of motion. Movement is part of everyday experience, so it is important to be able to analyse and predict the way in which objects move. The behaviour of moving objects is studied both graphically and through equations of motion.

components.title: Dynamics
content: The motion on any object is governed by forces that act on the object. The topic introduces Newton's law of motion, which are fundamental to understanding the connection between forces and motion. The concept of momentum and the use of momentum conservation to analyse interaction are also studied.

components.title: Forces, density, and pressure
content: In this topic, the natures of some different types of force are studied, including how foreces give rise to translational and rotational equilibrium. The concept of pressure is introduced. This acts as a starting point for later work in pressure on gases.

components.title: Work, energy, and power
content: The topic introduces different forms of energy, in both qualitative and quantitative terms. The concept of energy and its conservation provide useful accounting tools that help understand the behaviour of physical systems. The concepts of power and efficiency are also studied.

components.title: Motion in a circle
content: The turning effect of forces is introduced in Topic 5. In this topic, rotational motion, confined to motion in a circle is studies. Radian measure is introduced and equations for circular motion are developed, in terms of both angular and linear speeds.

components.title: Atoms, molecules, and stoichoimetry
content: The topic illiustrates how quantitative relationships can be established when different substances react. (The term relative formula mass or M will be used for all compounds, including ionic compounds)

components.title: Atomic structure
content: The topic describes the type, number and distribution of the fundamental particles which make up an atom, and the impact of this on some atomic properties.

components.title: Chemical bonding
content: The topic introduces the different ways by which chemical bonding and the effect this can have on physical properties.

components.title: States of matter
content: The study of the particles in solids, liquids and gases and the interaction between them is important in understanding the physical properties of substances.

components.title: Chemical energetics
content: Enthalpy changes and enthropy changes accompany chemical reactions. This topic demonstrates why some reactions are spontaneous and some are not.

components.title: Business and its environment
content: This topic area is concerned with understanding the nature and purpose of business activity and identifying the structure, functions, cultures, and objectives of different business organizations. Central to an understanding of buisness and its internal and external environments is a recognition that the world in whihc businesses operate is in a constant state of change. The impact of political, economic, social, technological, legal, environment and ethical factors and how these might influence business activity is considered. The extent to which businesses can respond and adapt to such change is likely to determine their success.

components.title: People in organizations
content: This topic area focuses on how businesses can develop and use policies, procedures, strutures, systems and approches to mangement and leadership that will harness the human potential whitin an organizatino and acheive organization goals. An understanding of the central role of effective management and leaderhsip in achieving efficiency and comptetitveness is required. Candidates will need to understand the distinct bodies of theory that underpin the concepts of business management and leadership. The importance of motivation techniques and theories in understanding employee needs to be considered. The contribution to business success made by human resource management through effective workforce planning and the recruitment, selection and training of workeers will also be explored.

components.title: Marketing
content: The topic area develops an understanding of the importance of the marketing function for business competitiveness. The significance of marketing orientation - the process of aligning a business to its operating environment, customers, other stakeholders and markets - is emphasized. An understanding of the principles and practices of marketing and their application to commercial and not-for-profit organizaitons is considered. The relationship between marketing and other buisness functions such as operations management, finance and human resource management is also considered. The application of marketing concepts and methods to assist marketing and buisness decisions is expolored. Central to the understanding of marketing is the objective of satisfying the needs and wants of customers through effective market research, applying and appropriate marketing mix and establishing an organization with a strong customer focus.

components.title: Operations and project management
content: Operations management is the discipline of how resources are managed to achieve the efficient production/provision of goods and service. Project management is the discliple of managing resources to successfully complete one-off projects. This topic area promotes understanding of operations and project decision and how design, planning, quality and workforce issues interrelate to achieve operations and project objectives. Candidates should develop an understaning of the benefits and limitations of a variety of techniques and analytical frameworks used by operations and project managers. Central to the understanding of how successful operations and project management suppport effective manufacturing and service businesses is a recognition of the importance of innovation in product and service delivery in dynamic and volatile business environments.

components.title: Finance and accounting
content: The topic area introduces candidates to the importance of the management of finance, the keeping of an analyis of accounts, and the assessment of buisness financial management; the value of financial statements and some key accounging techniques used to promote profit, measure performance and exert control in bvuiness organizaitons; the use of financial management information in managerial decision making; the links between financial management and other management activity; the importance of identifying and interpreting management accounting information, recognizing uses and limitations. Central to the role of finance and accounting is an understanding of how information can be used to create and measure value.

components.title: The Family
content: This unit examines the family and how and how processes of social change have affected it

components.title: Theory and Methods
content: This unit contains two central aims. First, it introduces candidates to key concepts and theories associated with a socilogical understanding of human behaviour. Candidates begin to explore the nature and sociological enquiry and the insights that it provides into the relationships between individuals and social structures. Second, the unit introduces candidates to the basic concepts and issues in research design and evaluation. The aim is to make candidates aware of the way in which sociologists can claim that their findings are truthful and worthwhile.

components.title: Education
content: In this unit candidates examine an important source of secondary sociolization and study in more detail the issues of inequality, power, control and ideology.

components.title: Global Development
content: In this unit candidates examine processes of global development and consider the nature of social inequility on an international scale.

components.title: Media
content: In this unit candidates examine how the media are organized, how they represent different issues and social groups, and what effects they have on individuals and societies.

components.title: Religion
content: In this unit candidates develop their understanding of religion in its social context. The aim is to explain different explanations of the role of religion in society and to understand the nature of religious movements and the factor influencing the level of religiosity in particular communities.
